Fig. 1 SEM image of RM (a), SEM image (b), HRTEM images (c and d), and dislocation analysis image (e) of RMH-800. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 RMH-800 EDS elements distribution mapping. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Adsorption and desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of RMH-800 (a) and RM (b). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 FT-IR spectra (a) and H2-TPR spectra (b) of the as-synthesized materials. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD spectra of RM (a) and samples prepared with different temperatures (b). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XPS spectrum of the RMH-800 and RM. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The high resolution Fe 2p spectra of RMH-800 (a) and RM (b). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Activity of catalysts prepared at different temperatures (a), activity comparison chart (a) and XRD comparison (c) of RMH-800 and RMB-800, activity at pH= 3 (d), activity at pH= 4 (e) and XRD spectrum (f) of Fe2O3 -H2-800 and Fe3O4 -H2-800. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The graph of catalyst kinetic fitting (a), the decolorization rate of ARG during typical Fenton degradation process (b), the degradation rate (c) and the adsorption rate (d) of drugs. The zero-valent iron (ZVI) heterogeneous Fenton catalyst based on red mud (RM) was synthesized by direct reducing iron oxide in RM using H2 at 800 °C (RMH-800). X-ray diffraction analysis showed that Fe2O3 in RM was reduced to Fe0. Brunauer -Emmett-Teller, scanning electron microscopy and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy show that RMH-800 is a ZVI-loaded porous material. The catalysts were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Under the conditions of 2.86 mM H2O2, 100 mg/L Acid Red G (ARG) and 1 g/L RMH-800, 95 % of ARG was removed within 10 min. The RMH-800/H2O2 system also showed excellent degradability to antibiotics (Sulfamethoxazole, Ibuprofen and Primidone). •OH is the main species responsible for pollutants degradation. RMH-800 showed low iron leaching during the reaction process and excellent catalytic performance even after 6 repeats, indicating it a stable and low-cost material with great potential for wastewater treatment. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Red mud ZVI Wastewater treatment Heterogeneous Fenton catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Red mud (RM) is an industrial waste produced during the production of alumina using the Bayer process. For each ton alumina produced, approximately 1–2.5 tons RM is generated [1,2]. In 2017, global RM production increased by about 150 million tons per year, with the cumulative stockpile exceeding 4 billion tons and still growing rapidly [3,4]. RM has the characteristics of high yield, high alkalinity and complex composition, which is a serious environmental issue [5]. RM is a mixture of iron-rich minerals, with the percentage of Fe2O3 varying between 15.2 % and 62.8 % depending on the source [6]. However, only a small amount of RM can be used as construction materials [7], metal recycling [8], land composting and environmental remediation materials [9,10]. Currently, the most common disposal method for RM is still landfill treatment [11]. This introduces a high risk of contamination to soil and groundwater, and the iron source in RM is not effectively utilized. Therefore, there is an urgent need for economic and environmental protection of RM treatment strategies. Synthetic dye is a very common organic pollutant in most water bodies, which has strong stability in the environment [12]. The discharge of dyes in water will not only change the color of water, but also affect the life and health of human and animal. Most synthetic dyes can cause mutagenesis [13] and cancer [14]. In order to maintain human health and the harmony of ecosystem, it is very necessary to remove harmful dyes in water. In recent years, advanced oxidation process (AOPs), which decomposes organic matter by activating oxidants such as hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) or peroxmonosate (PMS) to produce free radicals, has been widely used in wastewater treatment [15–17]. Typically, these oxidants are activated by a variety of means, including transition metals [18], carbon materials [19], and external energy (light [20], ultrasound [21], and electrical energy [22]). Among them, Fe-based catalyst has the advantages of low biological toxicity and abundant geological reserves [23,24], so it has been applied more and more widely in AOPs recently [25–27]. Due to the high iron content in RM and the lack of effective treatment means, if it can be used as a kind of heterogeneous Fenton catalyst to activate H2O2, it can not only make reasonable use of the iron source in RM, but also solve the environmental issues that may be caused when treating RM. This will achieve the purpose of treating waste with waste. However, the direct application of RM as a catalyst is less efficient for the removal of organic matter because the Fe species in RM consists mainly of the less active Fe2O3 [28]. In recent years, due to its excellent reducing properties [29] and environmental friendliness [30], zero-valent iron (ZVI) has been widely used to degrade various organic pollutants [31–33]. Therefore, if the Fe2O3 in RM can be reduced to Fe0, it can not only be used as a catalyst for wastewater treatment, but also can solve the problems of easy oxidation and high iron leaching of Fe0 by its high alkalinity and good dispersibility [34]. In this work, an efficient and stable catalyst was prepared by calcinating solid waste RM at high temperature under H2 atmosphere. The catalyst exhibited very excellent catalytic activity and was able to maintain a high catalytic capacity after six cycles. The iron leaching was maintained at a low level during the reaction. The catalyst was applied to activate H2O2 for the degradation of Acid Red G (ARG) and several common antibiotics, and the reaction mechanism was studied in order to provide a research basis for further investigation of the preparation and application of RM-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 wt%), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98 %), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), methanol (CH3OH, 99.5 %), chloroform (CHCl3, 99.0 %), potassium iodide (KI), hydroxylamine hydrochloride (HONH2HCl), triiron tetraoxide (Fe3O4) and Acid Red G (ARG) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Ferric sesquioxide (Fe2O3) was obtained from Tianjin Hongyan Chemical Reagent Factory. 1,10-phenanthroline monohydrate (C12H8N2) was received from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) was obtained from Shanghai Bide Pharmatech Ltd. 2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidine (TEMP) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All chemicals were analytical grade without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 0.5 g of RM was loaded into a quartz boat and calcinated under H2 atmosphere. The temperature rised from 30 ºC to 800 ºC at a rate of 10 ºC/min, kept at 800 ºC for 2 h and then cooled naturally to obtain catalyst RMH-800. 0.5 g of RM was loaded into a quartz boat and calcinated under air atmosphere with the same temperature program to obtain catalyst RM-800. The control catalysts, Fe2O3-H2-800 and Fe3O4-H2-800, were prepared using Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 as raw materials with the same temperature program. 2.3 Characterization methods X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were determined on an X-ray diffractor (PANalytical, X′pert MPD Pro X, Cu Kα 40 kV 40 mA). The surface morphology of the samples was examined with scanning electron microscope (Zeiss Gemini SEM 500). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the samples was taken from Thermo Fischer Talos F200X Lorenz transmission electron microscope with the accelerating voltage of 200 kV during shooting. Builder SSA-4300 was used for multi-point Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) measurements of specific surface area of samples. The pore size distribution of the samples was calculated by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The pretreatment method before the test was degassing at 105 ºC for 2 h. The concentration of iron in the reaction solution was measured by UV-2600A spectrophotometer. Thermo Fisher ESCALAB Xi+ instrument equipped with monochromatized X-ray Al Kα was used to measure the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of the samples. The results were analyzed by XPSPEAK41 software, and 284.8 eV of C 1 s was used as the standard energy level for calibration. In the process of analysis and fitting, the peak-area ratio of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 was set at 2:1. A Bruker TENSOR37 infrared spectrometer was used to determine the Fourier-Transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy of the samples, the resolution was 4 cm−1. A Builder PCA-1200 was used to test the temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) process. In H2 (5 vol%)/Ar atmosphere, the heating rate of the samples was 10 ºC/min. A Bruker A300-9.5/12 Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer was used to test the EPR spectras of the samples at 25 ºC. 2.4 Catalytic activity test 2.4.1 Degradation of ARG The performance of adsorption and catalytic activity of the catalysts were tested using anionic azo dye ARG as a simulated pollutant. In every test, 20 mL ARG (100 mg/L) with initial pH of 3.0, was added in 50 mL beakers. Then keep the solution temperature at 30 ± 0.5 ºC in a thermostatic water bath. Add catalyst (1.0 g/L) and H2O2 (2.4 mmol/L, if needed) at the same time, and trun on the magnetic agitator to start the reaction. The 1.0 mL reaction mixture was extracted at regular intervals and filtered. Its absorbance at 506 nm was determined by UV–visible spectrophotometer (UV-2600A) (in a colorimetric dish with an optical path length of 0.5 cm) [35]. The decolorization ratio R D (%) and adsorption ratio R A (%) of ARG were calculated by the following Eq. (1): (1) R % = A 0 − A t A 0 × 100 % where A 0 and A t were the initial and real-time absorbance of ARG, respectively [36]. To identify the active species that played a major role in the degradation of simulated pollutants, three free radical scavengers (methanol, KI and chloroform) were used, respectively. The concentration of methanol was 0.1 M, and the concentration of chloroform and KI were both 0.02 M. In addition, the EPR spectrometer was used to determine the signal of hydroxyl radical (•OH) captured by DMPO and 1O2 captured by TEMP at pH 3.0 and room temperature. In order to determine the leaching concentration of iron in the solution after the reaction, the method of phelloline - UV spectrophotometry was used [37]. During the catalyst cycling test, we recovered the catalyst after the reaction by filtering. After ultrasonic washing and drying, the recovered catalyst was added to the new reaction system. All parameters of the new reaction system were exactly the same as those of the previous reaction system. After the reaction was complete, the above operations will be repeated until the catalytic performance of the catalyst is significantly reduced or deactivated. 2.4.2 Degradation of drugs Primidone (PMD), ibuprofen (IBP) and sulfamethoxazole (SMX) were used as simulated contaminants to test the wide applicability of the catalyst. In each test, the initial concentration of drug was 0.1 mM, and the other reaction conditions were keep with ARG degradation condition. Then, 800 μL reaction mixture was extracted at regular intervals and filtered. The concentrations of drugs were determined by high performance liquid chromatography (TP-3100, Dalian Yilite Analytical Instrument Co., LTD.), the test methods are as follows. Yilite P3100 HPLC pump, a Yilite UV3100 UV/vis detector, a RESTEK C18 column (pinnacle DB, 250 ×4.6 mm, and 5 µm particle size) and a Yilite S3100 autosampler were used to detect the concentration of three drugs. The mobile phase of IBP was 70 % acetonitrile + 30 % water + 0.1 % glacial acetic acid at a flow rate of 1.2 mL/min, the injection volume was 20 μL, the column temperature was 30 °C and the detection wavelength was 220 nm. The mobile phase of PMD was 60 % methanol + 40 % water + 0.1 % phosphoric acid at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min, the injection volume was 20 μL, the column temperature was 30 °C and the detection wavelength was 218 nm. The mobile phase of SMX was water-acetonitrile-triethylamine (80:20:0.2) (pH adjusted to 5.9 by glacial acetic acid) at a flow rate of 1.2 mL/min, the injection volume was 20 μL, the column temperature was 40 °C and the detection wavelength was 240 nm. The above three mobile phases need to be filtered and ultrasonic before being used to remove impurities and bubbles. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst morphology and structure 3.1.1 SEM and TEM SEM and TEM were used to detect the surface configuration of RMH-800 ( Fig. 1). Due to the large metal oxide content in RM, the SEM image of RM shows a clear block crystalline structure (Fig. 1a). The SEM image of RMH-800 shows a rough and irregular structure. The Fe species in RMH existed in the form of chain clusters, which may be caused by the magnetic interaction between the small particles (Fig. 1b) [38]. Analysis of high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images reveals the presence of crystal planes with lattice fringe spacing of 0.202 nm on the surface of RMH-800, suggesting the presence of (110) crystal planes of Fe0 (Fig. 1d) [39]. These results show that Fe0 in RMH-800 has good crystallization (Fig. 1e). TEM and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) were used to explore the element distribution on the surface of RMH-800 ( Fig. 2). The EDS elements distribution mapping clearly reveals the spatial distribution of Fe element in the catalyst. These images clearly reveal the uniform distribution of iron on the surface of the catalyst. 3.1.2 BET BET nitrogen adsorption and desorption method was used to determine the specific surface area of the catalysts. Both RM and RMH-800 are mesoporous materials, and there is little difference in pore size distribution between them ( Fig. 3). The specific surface area of RMH-800 is 14.17 m2/g, clearly larger than that of original RM (6.01 m2/g, Table 1). The total pore volume of RMH-800 is higher than that of RM, but the average pore size is smaller than that of RM. Combined with the specific surface area and SEM test results, RMH-800 shows more pores than RM. This phenomenon may be caused by the thermal decomposition of volatile substances and carbonates in the RM, which leads to the gas production and escape [40,41]. As a result, vacancy sites are constantly generated in the RM, and finally it becomes porous material. 3.1.3 FT-IR FT-IR was used to explore the existence form of Fe in the above materials. The stretching vibration of Fe-O at about 569 cm−1 could be clearly observed in spectrum of the original RM [42]. This indicates that Fe in RM mainly exists as an oxide state. Fe-O still exists in RMH-600 produced by hydrogen reduction at 600 ºC. When the reduction temperature rises to 800 ºC, the stretching vibration of RMH-800 at 569 cm−1 completely disappears ( Fig. 4a). This result indicates that with the increase of reduction temperature, the iron oxides in RM were gradually reduced to Fe0. 3.1.4 TPR The reduction process of iron oxide in RM was investigated by hydrogen temperature program reduction (H2-TPR). Obvious reduction peaks were observed in the interval of 500–700 ºC and 700–900 ºC (Fig. 4b). The reduction peak at 550 ºC corresponds to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 (Eq. 1) [38]. The reduction peak at 800 ºC corresponds to the reduction of Fe3O4 to Fe0, which shows a double peak, indicating that both Fe2+ and Fe3+ exist in the reduced species, and there are two reduction processes at this temperature (Eq. 2，3) [43,44]. This reduction process is also consistent with FT-IR test results, indicating the origin of Fe0 in RMH-800. (1) 3 Fe 2 O 3 + H 2 → 2 Fe 3 O 4 + H 2 O (2) Fe 3 O 4 + H 2 → 3 FeO + H 2 O (3) FeO + H 2 → Fe + H 2 O 3.1.5 XRD XRD test results show that there are many kinds of minerals in the original RM, and there are characteristic peaks at 32.9° and 35.5°, corresponding to the (222) face of Fe2O3 (PDF#39-0238) [45] and the (311) face of Fe3O4 (PDF#89-0691) [46]. It indicates that the iron species of RM mainly exist in the above two forms ( Fig. 5a). The XRD spectra of RMH-800 has obvious characteristic peaks at 44.7° and 65.0°, which represents the typical (110) and (200) faces of α-Fe (PDF#87-0721) [47]. At the same time, Fe3O4 characteristic peak (PDF#26-1136) exists [31], so it can be seen that both Fe3O4 and Fe0 exist in RMH-800 (Fig. 5a). This also explains the magnetic origin of RMH-800. By comparing the XRD patterns of the catalysts prepared at different temperatures, it can be found that the pyrolysis temperature plays a key role in the conversion process of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 and Fe0. When the preparation temperature is lower than 600 ºC, there is no characteristic peak of Fe0. However, when the preparation temperature was higher than 600 ºC, the characteristic peak of Fe3O4 (PDF#26-1136) gradually increased, and at the same time, the characteristic peak of Fe0 (PDF#87-0721) appeared (Fig. 5b). It is speculated that CO and CO2 were generated by pyrolysis of some carbonates in RM [41]，because the H2 flux in the tube furnace is lower than the gas flux in the TPR test, the reduction pathway of iron oxide changes under the combined action of CO, CO2 and H2 [5,48]，a small amount of Fe3O4 is converted to Fe0 in advance at 600 ºC [49]. When the preparation temperature increased to 800 ºC, the phase transition of iron species could be attributed to the reduction of iron oxide [5]. The characteristic peak of Fe0 was significantly enhanced, indicating that ZVI catalyst was successfully obtained. 3.1.6 XPS To further clarify the transition process of iron oxide to Fe0 with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the structure of the catalyst was characterized by XPS. Clear peaks of O, Fe, Al and Si showed in RMH-800 and RM, corresponding to the presence of oxides of these elements in RM ( Fig. 6) [50]. Fe 2p photoelectron spectroscopy of RMH-800 shows characteristic peaks at 706 eV (Fe0 2p3/2) and 718.8 eV (Fe0 2p1/2), which clearly indicate the existence of Fe0 ( Fig. 7a) [51]. In addition, peaks near 709.8 eV and 714.4 eV were observed, with binding energy close to 709.8 eV for Fe2+ and 714.4 eV for tetrahedral species of Fe3+ [52], which indicated the presence of iron oxides. These peaks showed that part of the surface of Fe0 was oxidized during preparation or preservation. For the Fe 2p photoelectron spectra of RM, the two main peaks at 711.1 eV and 724.8 eV can be regarded as the characteristics of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 in Fe2O3 and Fe3O4, respectively (Fig. 7b). XPS spectra showed that the iron species underwent phase transition during the preparation process. 3.2 Influence of different preparation conditions on catalyst 3.2.1 Influence of calcination temperature Comparing the activities of catalysts calcined at different temperatures in catalyzing H2O2 to degrade ARG, it could be seen that when the calcination temperature was lower than 800 ºC, the decolorization rate could only reach 20 % within 60 min. However, when the calcination temperature was increased to 800 ºC, the decolorization rate of ARG reached more than 90 % within 10 min, and the catalytic activity did not change significantly with the continuous increase of the temperature ( Fig. 8a). The above results can be attributed to the changes in the valence state of iron species [53]. According to the TPR results, more Fe2O3 is converted to Fe3O4 and Fe0 with the increase of temperature. Comparing the XRD patterns of catalysts prepared at different temperatures, it could be found that the characteristic peak of Fe0 appeared when the preparation temperature was higher than 600 ºC. With the continuous increase of temperature, the characteristic peak intensity of Fe0 increased continuously, and the peak intensity was the strongest at 800 ºC and did not change with the further increase of temperature. This is also confirmed by the FT-IR spectra of RMH-800, where the stretching vibration of Fe-O at 570 cm−1 completely disappears, indicating the almost complete transition of Fe from ferric oxide to Fe0. 3.2.2 The influence of H2 In the co-heating process between RM and H2, iron oxide can be reduced well, mainly depending on the good reduction performance of H2. At present, many studies have proved that materials containing a large amount of lignin, such as coconut husk and straw, can show good reduction ability in the process of high temperature carbonization [54–56]. Therefore, in order to explore the reduction effect of H2 in the preparation process, air and straw plus nitrogen were selected to replace H2 co-heating with RM under the same conditions, and two synthetic materials, RM-800 and RMB-800, were obtained. Fenton activity test was carried out on the above synthetic materials, in which the original RM and RM-800 did not show obvious decolorization effect on ARG. The decolorization rate of RMH on ARG could reach about 95 % within 10 min, while the decolorization rate of RMB-800 on ARG was only about 80 % within 60 min. The catalytic activity of RMH-800 was much higher than that of the other three materials (Fig. 8b). By comparing the XRD patterns, it can be seen that there is no obvious Fe0 characteristic peak in RM and RM-800, while there are Fe2O3 characteristic peak (PDF#39-0238) and Fe3O4 characteristic peak (PDF#89-0691) in both RM, indicating that the iron oxide in RM has not been well reduced. However, the characteristic peak of Fe0 exists in both RMB-800 and RMH-800, but the intensity of the characteristic peak of Fe0 in RMB-800 is low, indicating that only part of the iron oxide is reduced (Fig. 8c), which is consistent with its lower catalytic activity compared with that of RMH-800. By referring to the application of biomaterials in the reduction of RM, it can be known that the calcination temperature usually needs to reach 900 ºC to achieve a better reduction effect [5,53]. The above experimental results show that the reduction ability of straw and air on iron oxide in RM is much lower than that of H2 at 800 ºC. 3.2.3 The influence of RM There are many minerals in RM. In order to explore whether they can affect the reduction of iron oxide in the process of high temperature calcination, pure iron oxide was selected as the iron source to co-heat with H2. Fenton activity test of the two synthetic materials showed that the decolorization rate of RMH-800, Fe2O3-H2-800 and Fe3O4-H2-800 on ARG could reach about 95 % within 10 min at the reaction pH of 3 (Fig. 8d). The amount of iron leaching after the three reactions were 0.95 mg/L, 14.9 mg/L and 15.6 mg/L, respectively. When the reaction pH was increased to 4, RMH-800 could still achieve the decolorization rate of ARG to about 90 % within 10 min, while Fe2O3-H2-800 and Fe3O4-H2-800 could only achieve the decolorization rate of ARG to about 80 % within 60 min (Fig. 8e). By comparing the XRD patterns, it can be seen that the peak patterns of Fe2O3-H2-800 and Fe3O4-H2-800 are completely consistent with those of commercial ZVI, indicating that both can be completely reduced by H2 at 800 ºC, and other minerals in RM do not affect the reduction process of iron oxides (Fig. 8f). However, in the process of Fenton reaction, the iron leaching amount of Fe2O3-H2-800 and Fe3O4-H2-800 were much higher than that of RMH-800 under the condition of pH = 3, although there was little difference in the reactivity of the three. However, when pH > 3, the catalytic activities of Fe2O3-H2-800 and Fe3O4-H2-800 were significantly reduced, which proved that RMH-800 had better catalytic stability. 3.3 Heterogeneous Fenton activity of catalyst The anionic dye acid red G (ARG) was selected as the model contaminant to evaluate the adsorption and catalytic performance of RMH-800. All the kinetic reactions were carried out at pH 4. According to the linear relationship of ln(Ct/C0) vs time, the removal of ARG by RMH-800 fits pseudo-first-order kinetics ( Fig. 9a). The addition of H2O2 alone had almost no decolorization effect on ARG, and the degradation rate constant was 0.00018 ± 0.00032 min−1. When RMH-800 alone was used as a control test without adding H2O2, no obvious decolorization of ARG was observed, indicating that RMH-800 had a weak adsorption capacity for ARG. When RM alone was used, the degradation rate constant of ARG was 0.0013 ± 0.0002 min−1, indicating that the original RM was difficult to catalyze the decomposition of H2O2. When both RMH-800 and H2O2 were used, the decolorization rate of ARG could reach more than 90 % within 10 min (Fig. 9b), and the degradation rate constant was 0.937 ± 0.093 min−1, indicating that RMH-800 could effectively catalyze H2O2 decomposition of ARG. Compared with the activity, it can be seen that under the condition of pH 4, using ZVI powder as catalyst could only decompose ARG by 80 % within 60 min (Fig. 9b), and the degradation rate constant was 0.036 ± 0.001 min−1, which indicated that the catalytic performance of commercial iron powder was far lower than that of RMH-800. In addition, the catalytic performance of different Fe-based catalysts reported in recent years is summarized ( Table 2). Among them, RMH-800 showed excellent catalytic activity. In addition to dyes in printing and dyeing wastewater, the degradation effect of RMH-800 / H2O2 system on some common drugs was also tested. PMD is a drug used to treat epilepsy and psychiatric disorders, which is low biodegradable in wastewater [62]. SMX, an isooxazole compound, is one of the most commonly used sulfamethoxazole drugs in human medicine [63,64], IBP is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) with certain toxicity and refractory properties [65]. RMH-800 was used as a heterogeneous Fenton catalyst to degrade the three drugs to test its catalytic applicability. The concentration of the three drugs was 0.1 mM, and the other reaction conditions were the same as those of the dye degradation system. According to the linear relationship of ln(Ct/C0) vs time, the removal of the three drugs by RMH-800 is consistent with pseudo-first-order kinetics (Fig. 9a). After reacting for 20 min, the removal rates of the three drugs all reached 70 % (Fig. 9c), and the degradation rates of PMD, SMX and IBP were 0.114 ± 0.017 min−1, 0.111 ± 0.020 min−1 and 0.128 ± 0.017 min−1, respectively. At the same time, the adsorption capacity of RMH-800 for the three drugs was tested without adding H2O2, and no significant change in drug concentration was observed (Fig. 9d), indicating that RMH-800 had no effective adsorption capacity for drugs, and the removal of the three drugs was mainly due to the degradation effect of heterogeneous Fenton. These results clearly indicate that RMH-800 is a highly active heterogeneous Fenton catalyst for the organic pollutants degradation. It should be noted that the amount of iron leaching in the supernatant of the reaction solution using RMH-800 was 0.95 mg/L, while the Fe leaching concentration of iron powder was higher than 10 mg/L. There are two main reasons for this phenomenon. First, RM itself has a high alkalinity and contains a large amount of alkaline carbonate, which can release a certain alkalinity and form a buffer system when it is put into an acidic environment, and the pH of the system can be well maintained between 4 and 5, and the leaching of iron ions can be effectively inhibited at this pH. Second, the RM calcined at high temperature in H2 atmosphere has a rough surface and porous structure, which can serve as a skeleton for the attachment of active species in the catalyst [66], which can reduce the amount of iron leaching during its use. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism In order to determine the main active substances in the process of H2O2 activation catalyzed by RMH-800, the removal rate of ARG with the addition of free radical trapping agent was evaluated ( Fig. 10a). The ARG solution almost did not fade after methanol (·OH scavenger [67]) was added. The addition of KI (surface reaction inhibitor [68]) also showed no significant catalytic ability, and the dye had almost no degradation effect. However, the addition of chloroform (O2•- scavenger [69]) did not have any significant effect on degradation kinetics, indicating that O2 •- did not cause ARG degradation. Based on the above results, it can be inferred that the degradation of ARG mainly depends on the oxidation capacity of •OH. At the same time, the surface reaction mainly occurs on RMH-800, which is a very typical heterogeneous Fenton oxidation reaction. It is generally believed that •OH can oxidize coumarin to 7-hydroxycoumarin (7-HOC), which can be measured by monitoring the fluorescence emission at about 460 nm by 332 nm light excitation [70]. In order to further explore the active species produced in the H2O2 decomposition reaction initiated by RMH-800, coumarin was added to the RMH-800/H2O2 system, and the supernatant was taken for fluorescence emission spectroscopy test after 15 min of reaction. The test results showed that there was an obvious fluorescence emission peak at 460 nm, while H2O2 and RMH-800 alone did not show this peak, which confirmed that •OH was produced in the RMH-800/H2O2 system (Fig. 10b). Then EPR test was performed, RMH-800 was added to H2O2 solution and DMPO was used as a free radical trapping agent. DMPO-OH• complex with intensity ratio of 1:2:2:1 was observed (Fig. 10c) [71]. When TEMP was used as a trap, the characteristic spectrum of isometric triplet of TEMP-1O2 complex was not observed in the EPR test results [72], which indicated that no 1O2 was produced during the activation of H2O2 by RMH-800 (Fig. 10d). Therefore, the results of EPR test further confirmed the results of activity test, which showed that no 1O2 was produced in the system, and the degradation of ARG mainly depended on the oxidation of •OH. The Zeta potential of RMH-800 was measured to characterize the change of its surface potential. The surface of RMH-800 was positively charged at pH 2–8 ( Fig. 11a). As an anionic dye, ARG will be negatively charged on the surface of dye molecules after entering water. Therefore, when the surface of RMH-800 is positively charged, it will adsorb ARG and negatively charged intermediates generated in degradation to a certain extent due to electrostatic attraction, which will promote the degradation process. The pH value of the solution can greatly affect the valence of iron species, catalytic efficiency and the activity of free radical, therefore, it is an important factor affecting the catalytic activity of RMH-800. The effective removal of ARG in RMH-800/H2O2 system depended chiefly on the generation of highly reactive free radicals. Usually at high pH, the precipitation of Fe ions leads to the formation of ferric hydroxide on the surface of the catalyst, which acts as an electron barrier and inhibits the release of Fe2+ and e-, thus negatively affecting the degradation efficiency of ARG. Under acidic conditions, Fe0 can efficiently produce Fe2+ and catalyze the Fenton reaction (Eqs. 4, 5). Although acidic conditions will lead to rapid corrosion of Fe0, the alkaline substances in RM can form a good acid-base buffer system which can effectively protect Fe0. Thus, Fe2+ can be released slowly to maintain the better activity and stability of the catalyst. In the cycle experiment, RMH-800 could still decolorize ARG more than 95 % within 60 min after 5 cycles (Fig. 11b). (4) Fe 0 → Fe 2 + + 2 e − (5) Fe 2 + + H 2 O 2 + H + → Fe 3 + + •OH + H 2 O It can be seen from BET test results that the specific surface area (SBET), average pore size and total pore volume of the catalyst increased after 4 times of use ( Table 3), which is presumed to be due to the consumption of Fe0. In addition, the porosity and pore size distribution of the catalyst did not change much after the catalytic reaction ( Fig. 12a), indicating that the overall structure of RMH-800 did not change greatly. XRD characterization of the catalyst after reaction shows that compared with fresh RMH-800, the intensity of Fe0 characteristic peak in the catalyst after reaction decreased with the increase of cycle times (Fig. 12b). XPS results of the catalyst after the reaction shows that the peak representing Fe0 at 706 eV in Fe 2p disappeared and the proportion of Fe3+ increased (Fig. 12c). These results indicate that Fe0 in the catalyst was consumed and there was electron transfer between Fe0 and H2O2. The concentration of leached iron during the cycle was determined by ICP at a final pH of 5 (Fig. 12d). It can be seen that when the catalyst dosage is 1 g/L, the leaching iron concentration of the catalyst decreases from 1.16 mg/L to 0.069 mg/L with the increase of the cycle number. The low leaching rate of iron indicates that RMH-800 has good chemical stability. 4 Conclusion Using solid waste RM as iron source and H2 as reducing agent, a novel heterogeneous catalyst RMH-800 was prepared by calcination. It was used as an efficient hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) activator for ARG removal. Fe2O3 in RM was reduced to Fe0 in the calcination process, the calcination temperature and H2 were the keys to the formation of Fe0. RMH-800 showed high heterogeneous Fenton catalytic activity for dye(ARG) and drugs (SMX, IBP and PMD) removal with relatively low iron leaching concentration at 1.16 mg/L·H2O2 was mainly activated by Fe0 and Fe2+ in RMH-800 to produce •OH, and then ARG was degraded by •OH. In this process, the Fe0 in the catalyst played a major role in the activation of H2O2. This study shows that the RMH-800/H2O2 system has great potential to remove various organic pollutants from water. coredata.dc:description: The zero-valent iron (ZVI) heterogeneous Fenton catalyst based on red mud (RM) was synthesized by direct reducing iron oxide in RM using H2 at 800 °C (RMH-800). X-ray diffraction analysis showed that Fe2O3 in RM was reduced to Fe0. Brunauer -Emmett-Teller, scanning electron microscopy and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy show that RMH-800 is a ZVI-loaded porous material. The catalysts were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Under the conditions of 2.86 mM H2O2, 100 mg/L Acid Red G (ARG) and 1 g/L RMH-800, 95 % of ARG was removed within 10 min. The RMH-800/H2O2 system also showed excellent degradability to antibiotics (Sulfamethoxazole, Ibuprofen and Primidone). •OH is the main species responsible for pollutants degradation. RMH-800 showed low iron leaching during the reaction process and excellent catalytic performance even after 6 repeats, indicating it a stable and low-cost material with great potential for wastewater treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation and application of red mud-based heterogeneous Fenton catalyst
